awd_titl_txt: Learning from the PROSE: Exploring professional organizations' role in supporting Black engineering student success
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite millions of federal investments to broaden participation, Black students continue to be underrepresented at all levels of engineering. Existing research not only provides evidence of the barriers to undergraduate engineering degree completion, it also reveals factors that positively influence the academic outcomes of high-achieving Black students. Factors like being more socially integrated on campus and being conscious of one's racial identity are among them; and involvement in certain types of professional organizations on campus provide a context for both of these factors to occur. As part of Learning from the PROSE (Professional Organizations Supporting Excellence), the aim of this study is to understand how students' engagement with identity-related organizations - like the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE) and those that makeup the National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC)- contributes to the successful completion of engineering programs.  This project is focusing on the experiences of those who have already successfully completed their undergraduate education, namely Black graduate engineering students. The findings from this study will advance our understanding of the unique role identity-related organizations play in promoting the success of one of the least represented groups in engineering. The explicit focus on Black engineering graduate students who have graduated from a range of institutions allows us to deeply explore similar dynamics in different contexts. By extension, this will allows us to develop a robust set of strategies for supporting minority students at all levels of education, reinforce the efforts of professional organizations that align with various dimensions of their identity, and shed light on pathways to the professoriate.

Although Black people represent approximately 13% of the U.S. population and are one of the fastest growing demographics in the nation, they made up less than 4.4% of engineering degree recipients at the undergraduate, Master's and doctoral levels during the 2015-2016 academic year. This work will learn from Black engineering graduate students that have successfully navigated engineering environments and self-selected to continue study in a graduate engineering program. Using the Model of Co-Curricular Support and Community Cultural Wealth as theoretical underpinnings, this qualitative and video-based research project will investigate how engagement in identify-related organizations as undergraduate students contributed to the successful navigation of their engineering programs. More specifically, this project aims to investigate the mechanisms by which professional organizations provide the critical professional and psychosocial support that contribute to the development and success of Black engineering students using a three-phase approach: performing a systematic literature review, conducting phenomenological interviews, and exploring novel means of dissemination. Although existing research typically investigates such experiences while being enrolled in undergraduate engineering programs, using a phenomenological approach, this study takes a comprehensive and reflective view that can only be obtained after the experience is over. Moreover, relying on a mixture of qualitative and video-based methods provides the basis for disseminating the research findings in traditional and novel ways. This study will uncover critical aspects of access to networks and support systems from the perspective of Black engineering students that have demonstrated persistence while highlighting partnership opportunities among existing on-campus programs that could promote a shift away from the siloed approaches to supporting student success. This study will also develop knowledge by serving as an initial investigation into the significance of engaging in multiple identity-related professional organizations simultaneously. Insights emerging from this investigation will likely have implications for other underrepresented groups (e.g., Latinx, LGBTQ, transfer students, etc).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The "Learning from the PROSE (Professional Organizations Supporting Excellence)” project amplified the voices of an overlooked population: Black engineering graduate students. It investigated how identity-based professional organizations, such as the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE) and National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) organizations, influenced student success, persistence, and well-being.This award-winning research, recognized with the 2024 William Elgin Wickenden Award for Best Research Paper in the Journal of Engineering Education and the 2022 STEM for All Video Showcase Award, has reshaped conversations in engineering education. The project has driven institutional policy change, expanded equity frameworks, and established critical support structures for Black graduate students. Over the course of this award, "Learning from the PROSE" has significantly advanced the study of race, graduate education, and lived experiences in navigating engineering. Through research, mentorship, and community-building, this work has:

Advanced Research on Race and Graduate Engineering Experiences. Expanded knowledge on how professional organizations shape Black engineering students' experiences. A systematic literature review (SLR) synthesized knowledge on professional organizations’ role in Black student success. Findings were published in Studies in Engineering Education. Through 37 phenomenological interviews, new insights emerged on Black graduate students’ experiences, including:

• Professional organizations as counterspaces, fostering identity, mentorship, and support.

• Mental health challenges, particularly in predominantly white institutions.

• The crucial role of professional organizations in academic and professional success.

• A framework for values prioritized by Black students in times of crisesThese findings continue to inform national conversations on race, identity, and racialized experiences in engineering, shaping institutional policies, faculty development, and equity initiatives.

Developed Human Talent Development through Broader Impacts. This project has cultivated human talent at multiple levels, including postdoctoral scholars, graduate researchers, and undergraduate students through the fostering of research expertise, mentorship, and professional growth. Specifically, it has supported:

• Two postdoctoral researchers, trained in qualitative research, academic publishing, and mentorship.

• Graduate research assistants, developing expertise in engineering education research, cultural epistemologies, and equity frameworks.

• Undergraduate Research Experience (REU) participants, exposed to STEM education research and encouraged to pursue graduate studies. The PI has recruited two REU participants into engineering education PhD programs.

Additionally, faculty and administrators engaged in this project have gained greater awareness of systemic barriers facing Black engineering students, prompting new institutional conversations about faculty development, mentoring, and student support.

Influenced institutional policies, advocating for systemic change in engineering education. Findings from this research have informed institutional policies and national STEM equity efforts. PI Coley’s presentation of data describing Black engineering graduate students’ experiences navigating at the intersection of two pandemics (COVID and systemic racism) at the 2021 National Society of Black Engineers’ Annual Dean and Minority Engineering Program Roundtable helped bridge research with institutional decision-making. 

Development of the BE GREAT Retreat. Created lasting infrastructure through the BE GREAT Retreat, now a highly regarded annual event. One of the project’s most transformative initiatives is the BE GREAT Retreat (Black Engineering Graduate Empowerment Retreat). What began as a data collection platform has grown into a widely recognized annual event, providing Black engineering PhD students with a dedicated space for wellness, values, community, and hope. Students have embraced this sacred space, finding it to be a lifeline amid the challenges of graduate school. 100% of attendees have affirmed the retreat’s positive impact on their academic and personal well-being, solidifying its role as a key intervention for student success. The retreat will hold its second annual offering, drawing more participants and reinforcing the necessity of intentional spaces of support in STEM.

Impact Beyond Science and Technology. This work has redefined success in STEM, emphasizing mental health, identity, and community as essential components of persistence. It challenges engineering institutions to move beyond technical excellence and recognize the role of well-being in student retention. By bridging academic, social, and psychological factors, this research underscores that professional organizations are critical social infrastructure in STEM. The project’s findings advocate for stronger partnerships between universities and identity-based organizations, ensuring that Black graduate students not only persist but thrive.

Moving forward, this work will continue through publications, the development of the docuseries, and ongoing institutional engagement. The power and merit of this research are undeniable, as evidenced by its national recognition, award-winning scholarship, and tangible impact on student success. With continued funding, this work will remain at the forefront of efforts to reshape engineering education, ensuring Black graduate students in STEM have the support, community, and resources they need to excel.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2025
Modified by: Brooke C Coley

The power and merit of this research are undeniable, as evidenced by its national recognition, award-winning scholarship, and tangible impact on student success. With continued funding, this work will remain at the forefront of efforts to reshape engineering education, ensuring Black graduate students in STEM have the support, community, and resources they need to excel.
